image.altText: Building erupts into flames in Gaza

items.synopsis: Israeli defence chiefs are facing growing questions following Hamas attacks that left more than 250 Israelis dead and 1,500 injured. Follow live.

title.children: Israel's security forces face questions over intelligence gaps as Hamas takes dozens hostage

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As the world has reacted to events in Israel overnight, there have been several leaders commenting about the need to contain the conflict and to de-escalate it. The Council of Foreign Relations (CFR) convened an expert panel and the first question asked was, well, what would an escalation look like? Lowy distinguished fellow in US-Middle East diplomacy at the CFR Martin S Indyk said: "I think there's a high potential for escalation just because Israel is inevitably going to retaliate in a very strong way, possibly—I would say at this point even likely — go into Gaza. And the result of that would be a very high loss of life on the Palestinian side." Indyk said the role of Iran in the attack on Israel was not yet clear. "But if this is coordinated, as I suspect it is, then I think we can see a situation where Hezbollah could well join in, and then we've got a regional conflagration the dimensions on which we have not seen," he said. "Hopefully we can head that off, but it's not going to be easy. There's a potential for eruption in the West Bank. Terrorist attacks against Israeli settlers would draw another harsh response in the West Bank. "There is a high potential for escalation."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What would an escalation look like?

props.alt: A screen grab of four men

children.content: CFR expert panel
As the world has reacted to events in Israel overnight, there have been several leaders commenting about the need to contain the conflict and to de-escalate it.
The Council of Foreign Relations (CFR) convened an expert panel
and the first question asked was, well, what would an escalation look like?
Lowy distinguished fellow in US-Middle East diplomacy at the CFR Martin S Indyk said:
"I think there's a high potential for escalation just because Israel is inevitably going to retaliate in a very strong way, possibly—I would say at this point even likely —
go into Gaza.
And the result of that would be a very high loss of life on the Palestinian side."
Indyk said the role of Iran in the attack on Israel was not yet clear.

"But if this is coordinated, as I suspect it is, then I think we can see a situation where Hezbollah could well join in, and then we've got a regional conflagration the dimensions on which we have not seen," he said.

"Hopefully we can head that off, but it's not going to be easy. There's a potential for eruption in the West Bank. Terrorist attacks against Israeli settlers would draw another harsh response in the West Bank.
"There is a high potential for escalation."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israeli defence chiefs are facing growing questions over how the disaster could have happened. Retired General Giora Eiland, a former head of Israel's National Security Council told Reuters Israel was surprised. "As we can see it, Israel was completely surprised, by a very well coordinated attack," he says. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's right-wing government has always made great play of its security credentials and taken an uncompromising stance towards the Palestinian militant factions including Hamas, which has controlled Gaza since 2007. However when the time came, Israel's security apparatus appeared to break down as a force of Hamas gunmen estimated in the hundreds by the military broke through security fences and scattered into towns. "This was an intelligence failure; it could not be otherwise," says Jonathan Panikoff, the US government's former deputy national intelligence officer on the Middle East. "It was a security failure, undermining what was thought to be an aggressive and successful layered approach toward Gaza by Israel," he said. An army spokesman told Reuters there would be discussions on the intelligence preparation "down the road" but for the moment the focus was on fighting. "We'll talk about that when we need to talk about it," he says. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel's security forces face questions over intelligence gaps

children.content: Israeli defence chiefs are facing growing questions over how the disaster could have happened.
Retired General Giora Eiland, a former head of Israel's National Security Council told Reuters Israel was surprised.
"As we can see it, Israel was completely surprised, by a very well coordinated attack," he says.

Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's right-wing government has always made great play of its security credentials and taken an uncompromising stance towards the Palestinian militant factions including Hamas, which has controlled Gaza since 2007.

However when the time came, Israel's security apparatus appeared to break down as a force of Hamas gunmen estimated in the hundreds by the military broke through security fences and scattered into towns.
"This was an intelligence failure; it could not be otherwise," says Jonathan Panikoff, the US government's former deputy national intelligence officer on the Middle East.
"It was a security failure, undermining what was thought to be an aggressive and successful layered approach toward Gaza by Israel," he said.
An army spokesman told Reuters there would be discussions on the intelligence preparation "down the road" but for the moment the focus was on fighting.
"We'll talk about that when we need to talk about it," he says.
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has been on Insiders this morning. Here's what he had to say on the situation in Israel and Gaza. "This is an abhorrent attack on Israel. This is indiscriminate, civilians being targeted, killed and murdered and many are being taken as hostages. "This is a dreadful circumstance that people didn't see coming, wasn't foreshadowed, a shock attack. "This action is ongoing. It must stop. Israel has a right to defend itself, which is what it is doing." Mr Albanese said: "Of course people worry about escalation but Israel has a right to defend itself and it will be doing so." "This is an attack on Israel by Hamas that has no precedent for what is occurring here." He said he believed all Australians were safe. "There are Australian Defence Force personnel, in the region, and at this point in time the advice ... is that no Australians are caught up. It's incomplete advice, this has been a very dark 24 hours." Watch the full video here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Anthony Albanese: 'Israel has a right to defend itself'

children.content: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has been on Insiders this morning.
Here's what he had to say on the situation in Israel and Gaza.
"This is an abhorrent attack on Israel. This is indiscriminate, civilians being targeted, killed and murdered and many are being taken as hostages.
"This is a dreadful circumstance that people didn't see coming, wasn't foreshadowed, a shock attack.
"This action is ongoing. It must stop. Israel has a right to defend itself, which is what it is doing."
Mr Albanese said: "Of course people worry about escalation but Israel has a right to defend itself and it will be doing so."
"This is an attack on Israel by Hamas that has no precedent for what is occurring here."
He said he believed
all Australians were safe.

"There are Australian Defence Force personnel, in the region, and at this point in time the advice ... is that no Australians are caught up. It's incomplete advice, this has been a very dark 24 hours."
Watch the full video here:

items.synopsis: Israel says it is now at war with Hamas, launching air strikes on Gaza and vowing to inflict an "unprecedented price" after dozens of Hamas militants broke out of the blockaded Gaza Strip and into nearby Israeli towns, killing hundreds and abducting others in an unprecedented operation.

title.children: 'We are at war': Israel retaliates with Gaza strikes after Palestinian militants kill hundreds and take hostages

image.altText: A boy next to a burning vehicle.

items.synopsis: Israel is responding to the biggest Hamas attack in years, but the seeds of the unrest were sown decades ago.

title.children: Israel and Hamas 'at war': How did we get here and how is it playing out?

image.altText: Two election placard - one for yes, one for no

items.synopsis: The ABC's poll of the polls now puts Yes at an average of 41.2 per cent, well behind No at 58.8 per cent, Casey Briggs writes.

title.children: How is the Voice polling with less than a week to October 14?

image.altText: Anthony Albanese standing in front of "VOTE YES" branding as he announces the date of the Voice to Parliament referendum

title.children: PM rules out legislating Voice if referendum fails

image.altText: Colleen Johnstone and Phil Bayley with their son Angus using a laptop computer.

items.synopsis: Angus isn't like most other year 11 students — it takes him a lot longer to read and understand information. His school gave him extra time at his mid-year exams which really helped. The trouble is, at finals, he won't get anywhere near that — and experts say that isn't fair.

title.children: Angus needs more time in exams to help his 'brain think', but he won't get it at his finals — and advocates say that's unfair

items.synopsis: Australian law enforcement has started solving missing persons and unidentified remains cases using official police access to private genealogy databases, which combined, hold the DNA records of millions of people around the world.

title.children: It's being called the biggest game-changer in forensic investigations since DNA testing

image.altText: A spacecrafts solar panel is visible in the foreground, a large grey orange asteroid in the background

items.synopsis: The Psyche mission will travel to an asteroid unlike any we've seen. Its investigations could shed light on how the Solar System and the planets formed.

title.children: This asteroid, worth an estimated $15,600 quadrillion, is the target of a new NASA mission

image.altText: A woman stands next to a busy street while wearing headphones.

items.synopsis: The "silent walking" trend on TikTok has highlighted how much we rely on audio distractions to get us through the day. But is it a problem?

title.children: 'Me and my thoughts? Sounds horrible': What the 'silent walking' trend says about us

items.synopsis: Jakarta's police are in the midst of a morality crackdown, raiding porn studios and targeting content creators. But adult performers say it won't do anything to stop Indonesians from accessing porn.

title.children: Siskaeee is Indonesia's best-known adult performer despite a ban on porn and risk of jail time

image.altText: An elderly woman in a red headscarf stands in front of a wall of family photos

items.synopsis: Aunty Ruth Hegarty lived through a cruel chapter in Australian history. Now aged 94, she's approaching the Voice vote with optimism for future generations.

title.children: 'This is truth-telling': At 94, Ruth Hegarty wants to you to hear her story before you vote

image.altText: Two men sitting at a table, smiling at the camera.

title.children: The men who know a different side to Volodymyr Zelenskyy

image.altText: A car park with an area taped off and police in attendance.

items.synopsis: The gunmen allegedly involved in yesterday's deadly shooting at a shopping centre in Melbourne's north remain on the run, as police reveal the attackers set two getaway cars on fire before fleeing in a third.

title.children: Alleged gunmen on the run after shooting at car park in Melbourne's north

image.altText: A photo of a man and a woman with their faces scribbled out.

items.synopsis: A letter from a stranger is all it took to spiral Martin into losing control of his own life. The disability royal commission has made recommendations to reform guardianship legislation, including gag laws that prevent Martin from speaking about his experience.

title.children: Martin isn't allowed to live at home or see his wife. A royal commission wants changes to help others like him

image.altText: A Tasmanian azure kingfisher sits on a bare branch against a dark background

items.synopsis: Dean has fallen in love with the elusive Tasmanian azure kingfisher, but fears not enough is being done to protect the species, which is one of 14 endangered native birds without a recovery plan.

title.children: It's estimated there are between 250 and 400 of these birds left in the wild — but there's no plan to save them

image.altText: Vertical gardens and a fountain.

items.synopsis: Singapore will soon join Dubai to provide travellers with a more efficient immigration clearance as early as 2024 following an update to its Immigration Bill.

title.children: Singapore to go passport-free but what are the risks and could Australia follow suit?

image.altText: A middle aged man wearing a head set, looks up at screens

items.synopsis: The Bathurst 1000 sees the Gen3 Supercars take to the mountain on the 60th anniversary of the great race. Follow all the updates in our live blog.

title.children: Tander bemoans 'frustrating' Bathurst penalty which drops his car from second to 26th

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Garth Tander has spoken to Fox Sports. He has just watched his teammate David Reynolds drop to 26th after serving a drive through penalty. He believes his team should have been allowed to give the position they illegally took from Broc Feeney back to him. "For as long as I can remember … they've given us the opportunity to redress that under the safety car," he says. "There was absolutely no instruction from race control to do that. "When we actually did it on track, they simply said 'no'. "Frustrating, disappointing, but ultimately there is a long way to go in this race."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lap 35: Tander bemoans 'frustrating' penalty

children.content: Garth Tander has spoken to Fox Sports.
He has just watched his teammate David Reynolds drop to 26th after serving a drive through penalty.
He believes his team should have been allowed to give the position they illegally took from Broc Feeney back to him.
"For as long as I can remember … they've given us the opportunity to redress that under the safety car," he says.
"There was absolutely no instruction from race control to do that.
"When we actually did it on track, they simply said 'no'.
"Frustrating, disappointing, but ultimately there is a long way to go in this race."

items.synopsis: As suburban sprawl radiates from cities across the country, experts say Australia needs more infill development. But building higher-density homes isn't always easy.

title.children: There's a bunch of issues impacting Australia's housing crisis. Then there's the 'Nimby Paradox'

items.synopsis: Hemp is one of the toughest plants on the planet and its potential uses range from bulletproof vests in the US to waterproof flooring for housing and other robust building products in Australia.

title.children: The bulletproof plant undergoing high-velocity growth

title.children: Weather scientists worry fast-warming oceans have warped BoM's El Niño index

image.altText: An abulance van is seen driving past pedestrians in traditional Afghan dress

title.children: Verstappen has gone from a driver with a clouded title to a champion equal with F1's greatest drivers

image.altText: Seven Australian players group together as they celebrate a wicket against West Indies in the women's ODI in Brisbane.

items.synopsis: Australia has West Indies on the back foot after dismissing the tourists for just 83 in the first ODI at Brisbane's Allan Border Field. Check out the live scores and stats in our ScoreCentre.

title.children: ODI live: Aussies rip through Windies as they chase victory in series opener

image.altText: A mother sits on a rug with her four of her children as they read and write on white sheets of paper.

items.synopsis: Thousands of people onshore and offshore are waiting for their asylum applications to be addressed, so what does the government's plan to spend $160 million improving processing speeds mean for those who haven't seen their family for years?

title.children: Shakila is hiding from the Taliban with her five children. A promise by the Australian government has given her hope

items.synopsis: From striking art installations to one-of-a-kind costumes, two designers are transforming marine debris into "beautiful things" that highlight a scourge that plagues our beaches.
